author: jeffrey.downard
title: Ethical AI for Singularity/Cardano
description: Системы искусственного интеллекта и машинного обучения имеют хорошо известные проблемы, обусловленные скрытыми предубеждениями и предрассудками. Как решить эти этические проблемы?

f6_assessments.q0: This seems like a diverse team who want to help teach the community through vidoes and work shops about combining ethics with AI, and teach about problems such as bias etc. This part I really like. I am not so sure about what is going on with the section on curating datasets for ethical AI to train Bayesian nets. This component seems like it needs some more focus. What is the point of this? Is it to create example for teaching about ethical AI? If you have a specific problem you are trying to solve there, please present it.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers have great experience and in the main the plan is well detailed and they should be able to deliver it.
f6_assessments.q2: Delivery of the majority of this proposal should be easy to asses progress upon. As mentioned above, just the component on seeking datasets to fit Bayesian nets too seems a little undefined. It would be good to see some goals for number of people attending the workshops and watching the videos to enable measurement of the success of the project.

f6_assessments.q0:
Ethics will be a major hurdle as AI integrates more in the present day world. To solve this problem we need to take a look at what ethics actually is. It is a sence of right or wrong based on logical thought processes. So then, is the problem that is attempted to be solved a machine-related problem or a human problem? So first the human problem needs to be solved and that entails the core question: 'Who decides what is just?' 
Doing research on this topic, gathering as much datasets as possible and creating think tanks is definitely a step in the right direction. However, there is a real danger here of censoring AI and thus creating a manipulated outcome that does not correspond with truth that should be taken into regard.
f6_assessments.q1: The project is very feasible as the founding team are in a related space to what is aimed at. The budget has been realistically determined and the prospected time for each phase can be done. In terms of feasibility there is only one factor that might pose a risk and that is in case there is no consensus reached on ethical problems.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal is sound and holds multiple necessary variables to easily audit it. There is even a reference list included. One thing that is lacking is an analysis of risk in terms of censorship. If that were to be added, the proposal would be improved.

f6_assessments.q0: Good proposal, It's actually something I personally haven't thought of but something so crucial for AI to be accepted by the masses. By providing data sets on ethical standards for ML you provide a structural barrier so that everyone can feel safe from AI. Although this begs the question how ethical will these data sets be if they are provided by a few?
f6_assessments.q1: The team behind the proposal does do not lack any experience to make this work. The first few months they will actively search for team memes to help them develop Ethical AI. We have a timeline and budget which are connected and give transparency on how much every step costs. Make sure to set boundaries in the project because ethicists and lawyers combined might become a heated battle.
f6_assessments.q2: Everything that is needed for an audit is available in the proposal. We have a website provided that gives insight on the team, a well mapped out timeline and we even have reference links presented at the bottom of the proposal. I have confidence that the progress of this proposal will be able to be assessed.

f6_assessments.q0:
The ethics of AI is important and has drawn a lot of attention, and it is a worthy area to explore in this challenge. However, the field is already a very broad and diverse area of study, with extensive research available, and this proposal attempts to address AI ethics more broadly than seems realistic. Proposed deliverables including outreach to scholars, development of videos, building of datasets for ethical AI (not clear what this means -- datasets are highly specific to particular AI application), case studies and workshops, but without specifics about what will be delivered in each of these areas. So while there is relevance to the challenge brief, there is insufficient specificity to articulate a useful project.

There is also a fairly limited articulated connection to SingularityNet other than to say that this is a "teachable moment" for Cardano and SingularityNet -- apparently meaning that they need to be told about ethics. I agree with that in principle, but again more specificity is needed.

This proposal gives the impression of having been put together without careful thought on specifics. This team is submitting a large number of proposals in Fund 7 -- some of them are significantly better on specificity than this one, which may have received less careful attention.

Because of the lack of focus and specificity, I disagree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
Although the team on this proposal plainly has experience related to AI ethics, the lack of specificity in this proposal makes it hard to conclude that it is highly likely that the proposal will be implemented successfully. 

For example, as mentioned above, it is not clear how the team would create "machine learning datasets for ethical AI". Doing so requires identifying a problem first before collecting data. 

More generally, the wide spread of other deliverables within the broad field of ethical AI  raises issues over how this all can be delivered.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal articulates a set of deliverables, but there is very little detail on what will be delivered. There are no quantified metrics of what will be delivered. Accordingly, I strongly disagree that the information provided is sufficient to audit the delivery and success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal has identified an extremely important element of future AI development and has effectively addressed the challenge. Ethical use of AI will be a critical component in shaping public opinion on the use of AI. This team seeks to create governance and education that will benefit the community.
f6_assessments.q1: The team is comprised by specialist AI, philosophy and blockchain practitioners. They appear to be very well placed to successfully implement the proposal and have voiced their intention of further collaboration with ethics researchers and stakeholders. The plan is well reasoned and makes for a clear roadmap with achievable KPI's. I like the aim of linking governance and education as this aspect is sorely needed.
f6_assessments.q2: The information provided is excellent and allows easy access to understanding the proposal aims and goals (with admission that much discovery still awaits). The budget is reasonable and viable although greater detail may have been appropriate. The KPI's are measurable and will allow the community to audit the ongoing progress and success of the project.

f6_assessments.q0:
It is an enormous impact on C.A. time to read and forensic each of your team projects and vCA time reading these comments more than 10 times again and over again.
Total fund requested $320100 of 12 proposals (inc two shell proposals, proposal number 11 and 12 listed in Feasibility). 
I could sum up three main areas that all of your 10 submitted projects as follow: 1) introduce PRISM + Cardano by using Youtube, website and workshops as delivery channels 2) developing PRISM at gathering data rather than an essential tool in Phase I (6 months) and 3) some intangible legal involving.

Most proposals paraphrased each other with minimal change. Here is one example. 

For example, Defining Success of 1) and 2) below are only difference "roadmap that small cities" vs 
"schematic model that" and the rest are IDENTICAL—the same fashion for the rest of the 12 proposals.
 
1) DIDs for Cities https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/DIDs-for-Cities/382636-48088
"Creation of a schematic model that use in the adoption of Atala Prism ID system. 
Development of webpage on the Kepler SCS website with videos presenting a narrative of the community conversation as citizens learn about the opportunities to create and take ownership of a secure digital I.D."

2) DIDs for Health Records https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/DIDs-for-Health-Records/382633-48088
"Creation of a roadmap that small cities can use in the adoption of Atala Prism ID system. Development of webpage on the Kepler SCS website with videos presenting a narrative of the community conversation as citizens learn about the opportunities to create and take ownership of a secure digital I.D."
f6_assessments.q1:

f6_assessments.q2:
Time and budget are close to identical pattern (copied/pasted)  with no detail and slightly differ in Dollar and not support-base and expected outcomes. There is no precise mechanism for Project Catalyst and the challenge team to follow and monitor your 10 proposals (minus 2 shell proposals).

Here is a summary "Time and Budget" pattens used in 10 submitted projects with the listed team member, Law Professor.

Phase I (6 months)

Month 1: some type of "outreach" (vary $$)
Month 1-2: "Workshops" (vary $$)
Month 2: Webpage development and and Youtube channel related (vary $$)
Months 2-3: identify the issue (vary $$)
Project direction:  (vary $$)
Project oversight and evaluation by members of Board of Advisors months 1-5: (vary $$)
Legal work on guidelines for the roadmap (vary $$)
Total: (vary $$)

Phase II (6-9)
Phase III (10-12)

solution: Мы развернем наборы данных для машинного обучения, нейронных сетей и байесовских сетей, которые (1) выявят предубеждения и (2) научат этическим нормам.
experience: Профессор этики и права, машинного обучения, логической теории, математической логики, искусственного интеллекта, консультант по бизнес-системам.
